unnormalised: ## Finding My Shanti: A Journey Through Yoga Practices
normalised: Finding My Shanti: A Journey Through Yoga Practices

unnormalised: My yoga journey began a few years ago, spurred by persistent back pain and a general feeling of being disconnected. I'd always admired the serene postures and calming presence of yogis, especially remembering my grandmother, Amma, who religiously practiced Surya Namaskar every morning, well into her 80s. I decided to finally give it a proper try.
normalised: My yoga journey began a few years ago, spurred by persistent back pain and a general feeling of being disconnected. I'd always admired the serene postures and calming presence of yogis, especially remembering my grandmother, Amma, who religiously practiced Surya Namaskar every morning, well into her eighties. I decided to finally give it a proper try.

unnormalised: My first class was at a small studio near my home in Bangalore called “Shanti Yoga Kendra”. It was a cozy space, maybe 600 sq ft, with natural light streaming in. I felt incredibly clumsy trying to keep up with the instructor, Priya. Trikonasana felt anything but comfortable! But there was something undeniably appealing about the focus and the conscious breathing (Pranayama) that followed each pose.

unnormalised: Over time, I explored different styles. Ashtanga felt incredibly challenging, pushing my physical limits in a way I hadn't experienced before. Hatha yoga, on the other hand, offered a gentler, more restorative practice. I even tried a weekend retreat at an Ashram in Rishikesh – early morning meditations by the Ganges, followed by hours of intense asana practice. It was transformative!

unnormalised: Now, my daily practice is a mix. I start with a few rounds of Surya Namaskar, then move into a series of asanas depending on how my body feels. Some days it's a vigorous Vinyasa flow, other days it's a quiet session of restorative poses. I always end with Savasana, allowing myself to fully relax and integrate the practice.

unnormalised: Beyond the physical benefits (less back pain, increased flexibility), yoga has brought a sense of calm and awareness into my life. I’m more mindful throughout the day, less reactive to stress, and more connected to my body. Even Dr. Sharma, my family physician, noticed a significant improvement in my blood pressure during my last check-up.

unnormalised: Yoga is not just about achieving perfect poses; it’s about the journey of self-discovery. It’s about finding your own Shanti, your own inner peace, one breath at a time. And honestly, it's probably saved me Rs. 5000 in massage therapy bills! Maybe I'll even master Sirsasana one day...maybe.
